columns.text: In this problem, we will solve for the discount rate that will make us indifferent between the two investment plans.

The discount rate refers to the interest rate that is placed when taking out short-term loans. In this situation, we will compare the interest rates of the two plans and determine at what rate the decision will become indifferent between the two.

Aside from this, we will also define the difference between annual perpetuity and annuity.

The main difference between these two is that annual perpetuity goes on for an infinite amount of time whereas annuity has a specific set amount of time.

Next, we will solve for the present value annuity of the other plan. This is given as:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Present value annuity}&=\text{Cashflow}\times \left(\dfrac{1-\left(\frac{1}{1+\text{r}}\right)^{\text{time}}}{\text{r}}\right)
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the given values, we will get the present value annuity as:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Present value annuity}&=\$47,000\times \left(\dfrac{1-\left(\frac{1}{1+\text{r}}\right)^{15}}{\text{r}}\right)
\end{aligned}$$

Just like in the Step 4, we will leave this as is since we cannot simplify it yet.

To get the rate that will make the choice indifferent, we will equate both the present value of annual perpetuity to the present value annuity. This will result in this equation:

$$\begin{aligned}
\dfrac{\$35,000}{\text{r}}&=\$47,000\times \left(\dfrac{1-\left(\frac{1}{1+\text{r}}\right)^{15}}{\text{r}}\right)
\end{aligned}$$

Simplifying the equation, we will get the interest rate that will make the two investment plans equal to each other.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{r}&=0.09529
\end{aligned}$$

This means that the interest rate is $9.529\%$
